g.text: . However, a two-phase quasi-equilibrium can also occur between two metastable phases
when their chemical potentials are identical. Metastable phase diagrams have been used to understand the forma-
tion of metastable phases via solidification
constructed a pseudo-binary equilibrium phase diagram by measuring the melting points of several Zr-based
-Zr and used the metastable phase diagram to explain the evolution of the different micro-
structures in their samples. However, they did not address the influence of the cooling rate on volume fractions
and compositions as well as they did not focus on the underlying mechanism. The current concept of a two-phase
quasi-equilibrium successfully reveals the influence of cooling rates and designed mole fractions of
microstructures of BMGCs as we discuss below.
be captured by continuous cooling transformation (CCT) curves. We use the quasi-equilibrium phase diagram to
construct a CCT curve for the present alloys (Fig. 3b). It is also the basis for discussing the differences in the crys-
talline volume fractions and compositions of the glass and
-Ti for BT48 samples produced with different cool-
ing rates (see above). The following temperatures are crucial here:

fields are established, the solidification behaviour under different cooling rates can be discussed qualitatively.
The cooling curves corresponding to the BT48 rods with a diameter of 2 mm and 6 mm intersect the
–line and thus go through the phase regions I, II, IV, and VI (Fig. 3b). Once the
-Ti precipitates in the supercooled liquid. Before the composition of the supercooled liquid or the dendrites
is traversed and the compositions and volume fractions are frozen in
due to the limited mobility of atoms. At the glass transition temperature the supercooled liquid finally vitrifies
and a BMGC is the outcome. In this cooling rate regime the composition and the volume fractions depend on the
cooling rates. For this reason one obtains identical phases in case of rod with 6 mm in diameter but dendrites are
Ti-richer and the glass is Ti-poorer compared to the rods with smaller diameters (
2 mm). At the same time the
crystalline volume fraction is somewhat larger because the system has a larger time window for
and the dendrite size increases as well. In contrast, the cooling curves representing the larger rods (
20 mm) as well as the 100 g ingot of BT48 intersect the
–lines, and go through regions I, II, III, V, and
VII (Fig. 3b) before the microstructure evolution is effectively halted at
. This in turn results in BMGCs in which
